content: They do. For customer support roles. They also pay some relocation money.
Nope. What about it

This guy's case - he needs lawyers. I dunno. Too complicated for me to dwell into right now and read about it. 
The work environment: just know your rights, read your contracts, read general info on what is required to be signed when starting a job. As well as what is not ok to be signed. Read properly your docs. Ask for them to send them in advance, so that you read through them. Or give you time at the office to read them. If they are unwilling to give you time to read, there is something fishy. When signing something, there are specific law articles mentioned in the contract. Check them out. Check what other types of regulations there are.
Know your rights and read through the local labour law. Read your payslip and make sure you understand it.
I might be looking for tech support person 2nd lvl for EMEA. 🤭 stay tuned
That's why I said read also articles that are related. Like types of employment contract, types of termination, etc
I'm about to board a flight. So talk to you later. <a:duckdance:833211055911600148>

<@229986947727228941> 
Something else. 
When you get told what to do and assigned tasks, ask for them to be in writing. With clear instructions, clear responsibilities, clear infornation, clear deadlines. If needed create yourself a template when you get a task assigned. Have that in writing, in emails for example. To be able to have a track record what was told and promised.

Blue collar jobs must be very strict in terms of health and safety regulations. There the company must comply with lots of things. So there I wouls recommend reading those HS requirements. Also proper job descriptions, instructions must be in place
You can't just do whatever you like and you can't order someone do whatever you like that is outside of their job description
When in doubt, look for your local labour inspection and give them a call. You can always consult with a specialist on your rights
At least that is something you can do here

I disagree here on the part saying that mentally you are at your prime between 19-23. 
If we take memory in particular it works in different ways for young people and those that are older. It may be quicker when you are young, you may memorise stuff easier, but in terms of ... let's call it 'wisdom' you know nothing John Snow. What younger people lack is life experience and knowledge how to tackle different situations that just happen you know.
thank you! Written with my fallen apart fingers 🤭

But to add here: I am 33 y.o. and honestly I feel at my prime right now. I have the life experience, I have a wonderful partner (yes, whatever you may think, fabo is actually a great guy, he usually sleeps in the bedroom with me, not the couch), I have a son. I am also developing nicely professionally and I feel pretty content
I don't think being mentally stable comes with age. It comes with working on yourself. I feel like the world would have been a much better place if everyone went to talk to a therapist now and then
I've also seen bad therapists, so... Who knows.
